These permissions are granted for the duration of the World Health Organization (WHO) declaration of COVID-19 as a global pandemic.']], 'copyright-year': [], 'ali:free_to_read': [], 'copyright-holder': []}, 'custom-meta-group': [{'meta-name': 'issue-copyright-statement', 'meta-value': '© Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest, Hungary 2023'}]}}
body: {'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('Higher education institutions are in competition to enhance regional growth and support global development strategies with the necessary highly qualified personnel and research (Al-Turki & Duffuaa, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR3">2003</xref>; Ho et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR26">2006</xref>). In such a competition among educational institutions, the awareness that is necessary to evaluate the quality of institutions effectively and objectively contributes to the increase in performance. Prospective students and their families consider university rankings to select a suitable university in terms of time, career prospects, and financial situations (Griffith & Rask, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR24">2007</xref>). Moreover, scientists, with whom scientific cooperation can benefit from many university rankings when deciding on the university they will go to for research. Therefore, evaluating the organizational effectiveness of higher education institutions is becoming more important to governments, universities, researchers, and students. In the context of organizational effectiveness, determining the degree to which an organization reaches its objectives is complex. The number of resources to produce a unit of output is difficult to measure in universities with multiple inputs, outputs, and stakeholders (Ball & Halwachi, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR10">1987</xref>). Fortunately, depending on developments in higher education, as long as the concepts of quality, efficiency, and accountability are more visible, performance evaluation processes can be\xa0managed more accurately in terms of teaching, research, and service quality indicators.', attributes={'id': 'Par2'}), StringElement('Higher education, especially in universities, involves many managerial and practical dimensions, such as human activities, limited resources, numerous actors, intense communication, etc., which need to be managed simultaneously. Due to the essentially conflicting criteria, the university\xa0ranking problem is a complex evaluation procedure that consists of more than one criterion by its nature (Azma, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR9">2010</xref>). Therefore, multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) approach, a branch of operations research and a systematic decision-making procedure on complex problems, can be considered an appropriate solution to handle the university\xa0ranking problem through evaluating multiple conflicting criteria. It is seen that some tangible quality criteria, which are measurable in units, are used in university performance improvement studies, such as teaching, research (Barnabè & Riccaboni, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR11">2007</xref>; Wu et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR63">2012</xref>), and international outlook (Aliyev et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR5">2020</xref>). Since tangible quality indicators are not sufficient to evaluate universities in the context of organizational theory, service quality indicators should also be included to make a more comprehensive evaluation (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR29">2020</xref>). Service quality indicators that cannot be measured in units directly are called intangible criteria and are defined as stakeholders\' satisfaction (students, researchers, lecturer, etc.). The service quality of universities should be improved to ensure the satisfaction of all stakeholders due to increasing competition in line with the increasing number of universities.', attributes={'id': 'Par3'}), StringElement('Due to the intangible nature of service quality indicators, the\xa0evaluation of these indicators depends directly on the perception of stakeholders. However, the expectations of stakeholders evolve according to the\xa0promised resources, their personal networks, and their status quo. Consequently, ranking universities\xa0that have different socioeconomic developments and provide disproportional opportunities\xa0according to perceived quality may present unfair results.', attributes={'id': 'Par4'}), StringElement('Researchers and theoreticians have focused on the university\xa0ranking problem and its extensions over the years. Using different optimization and sorting techniques for the university\xa0ranking problem is one of the most studied topics in the literature. Still, there are a limited number of studies on defining criteria and determining the weights of criteria. Therefore, this problem is discussed in this study.', attributes={'id': 'Par5'}), StringElement('Considering the above\xa0issues regarding the stakeholders’ satisfaction and academic process improvement, this study presents a two-stage evaluation methodology for the university\xa0ranking problem. In the first stage, universities are clustered according to tangible factors, before ranking universities based on student satisfaction. These tangible factors, the\xa0foundation year, the number of academicians, the number of students per academician, the number of citations per academician, and the number of academic outputs per academician, are accessible before the choice of a\xa0university. Such factors are preferred because of their representation strength of the promised resources in higher education. In this way, it is ensured that universities with common characteristics are ranked according to the satisfaction of students who have similar expectations and prefer similar universities. Furthermore, thanks to clustering, the university\xa0ranking methodology can be applied in a more sensitive, realistic, and effective manner.', attributes={'id': 'Par6'}), StringElement('In the second, a hybrid MCDM model is employed to rank universities by considering the following service quality criteria<bold>:</bold> "learning experience", "campus life", "academic support", "management", "learning opportunities and resources", and "personal development and career support". In the MCDM methodology, the criteria are weighted by the Interval Valued Neutrosophic Analytic Hierarchy Process (IVN-AHP) based on student opinion; then, the universities are ranked using Vlsekriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje (VIKOR) based on student satisfaction. In this context, VIKOR is extended with IVN-AHP for the first time in the literature.', attributes={'id': 'Par7'}), StringElement('VIKOR, one of the MCDM methods, focuses on the selection of the most suitable one among a set of alternatives under conflicting criteria or the ranking of the alternatives (Büyüközkan & Ruan, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR16">2008</xref>). VIKOR enables decision-makers to identify the compromise solution by evaluating conflicting criteria to reach a final decision. Compromising ranking determines a compromised solution, close to the\xa0ideal, that provides maximum \'group benefit\' for the majority and minimum individual regrets (San Cristóbal, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR48">2012</xref>). In this study, VIKOR is extended with IVN-AHP to obtain more systematic criteria weight determination and alternative evaluation.', attributes={'id': 'Par8'}), StringElement('To determine the relative importance of the criteria in the decision-making process, the criteria should be weighted according to the\xa0preferences of the\xa0decision-makers. Therefore, IVN-AHP is used to determine the weight of the criteria in this study. AHP is one of the MCDM methodologies based on a pairwise comparison of criteria and alternatives (Çavdur et al., 2018), enabling more appropriate decisions with a formal and systematic decision-making process. It has a structure that simplifies complex problems. Due to the nondeterministic environment, complexity and unreliable information arise when experts with different interests, loyalties, and cultures interact with a particular project or program to evaluate alternatives or criteria (Abdel-Basset et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR2">2019</xref>). The method sometimes does not reflect the human way of thinking, even if it receives information from experts (Ayyildiz & Taskin Gumus, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR7">2020</xref>). Therefore, IVN-AHP emerged by combining AHP with neutrosophic logic. Comparison values in IVN-AHP are used in a range of values, unlike AHP, where net values are used. Neutrosophic logic provides a more flexible tool for experts while expressing their opinions with inconsistent and incomplete information under uncertainty, especially when experts\'\xa0opinions are taken with linguistic evaluations in decision-making problems (Gulum et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR25">2021</xref>). Therefore, AHP is extended with a neutrosophic set, which was first proposed by (Smarandache, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR52">1999</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par9'}), StringElement('This study has three main contributions to the literature from different aspects. (i) The first methodological contribution is, to the best of our knowledge, the use of the integrated\xa0application of IVN-AHP and VIKOR. (ii) The second methodological contribution is the consideration of both tangible and intangible factors for university\xa0ranking thanks to performing clustering and MCDM consecutively. (iii) From the practical aspect, this study is the most comprehensive in terms of the number of evaluated universities and participating students. In this context, such a study that integrates a clustering method to the university\xa0ranking problem through MCDM emphasizes reflecting student requirements to universities in terms of universities assessment in a more sensitive manner and the importance of evaluation indicators determined by students with a procedure easy to understand and apply. Moreover, the neutrosophic set provides a representation of knowledge to cope with uncertainty and lack of information inherent in such problems that involve many students’ opinions of different faculties in evaluating the indexes for university rankings.', attributes={'id': 'Par10'}), StringElement('The rest of the paper is structured as follows. Section\xa0“<xref rid="Sec2" ref-type="sec">Literature review</xref>” presents a review of\xa0the literature on the university\xa0ranking problem. The proposed integrated methodology is given in section\xa0“<xref rid="Sec3" ref-type="sec">Proposed methodology</xref>”. The application of the proposed methodology for Turkish universities is presented in section\xa0“<xref rid="Sec7" ref-type="sec">The application</xref>”. In section “<xref rid="Sec11" ref-type="sec">Discussions and implications</xref>”, the discussion and implications are provided. Finally, the\xa0conclusions are presented in section\xa0“<xref rid="Sec14" ref-type="sec">Conclusion</xref>”.', attributes={'id': 'Par11'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': [], 'title': 'Introduction'}, attributes={'id': 'Sec1'}), DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('The literature review focuses on two subjects; the first focus is studies related to a\xa0better understanding\xa0of the factors affecting the choice of a\xa0university, and the second one is studies related to the evaluation of higher education institutions according to different perspectives. Additionally, since this study integrates clustering and MCDM through a holistic framework methodology for the university\xa0ranking problem, studies related to clustering or classification of universities are also reviewed.', attributes={'id': 'Par12'}), StringElement('Factors affecting university choice have been an attractive topic for researchers, especially over the last two decades. Soutar and Turner (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR54">2002</xref>) applied conjoint analysis to examine important factors affecting the choice of a\xa0university in Australia. Briggs (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR14">2006</xref>) surveyed to detect the determinants of undergraduate education preferences and conducted a factor analysis to obtain more meaningful results and categorize the\xa0determinants of undergraduate education institution choice. Briggs and Wilson (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR15">2007</xref>) examined the factors that affect the choice of a\xa0university in Scotland, especially the \'Information Supplied by Universities\' and \'Cost of the Package\' factors. It was observed that these factors were ranked 10th and 20th among 22 factors considered in university choice. Simões and Soares (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR50">2010</xref>) conducted a quantitative analysis to determine the factors affecting students\' decisions for university selection. They conducted a questionnaire survey on 1641 students who applied to the university for the first time. Sojkin et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR53">2012</xref>) performed a survey with 1420 Polish students to determine the factors affecting university choice and examine how these factors differ according to personal information such as gender, age, and family income level.', attributes={'id': 'Par13'}), StringElement('Recently, parallel to the increase in competition among universities, studies related to their evaluation have gained increasing attention from different perspectives such as overall performance (Aliyev et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR5">2020</xref>; Nazari-Shirkouhi et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR41">2020</xref>; Wu et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR63">2012</xref>; Zolfani & Ghadikolaei, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR68">2013</xref>), research capacity (Duc et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR20">2020</xref>; Su et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR55">2020</xref>), innovation (Chen & Chen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR19">2010</xref>), a department of a university (Muhammad et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR37">2021</xref>), sustainability (Arora et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR6">2020</xref>; Puente et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR46">2020</xref>), lean philosophy (Kazancoglu & Ozkan-Ozen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR32">2019</xref>; Klein et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR33">2021</xref>), and student viewpoint (Castro-Lopez et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR18">2021</xref>; Goyal et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR23">2021</xref>; Kabak & Dağdeviren, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR27">2014</xref>; Nanath et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR40">2021</xref>; Nojavan et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR42">2021</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par14'}), StringElement('One of the most common perspectives in ranking universities is the overall performance. Wu et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR63">2012</xref>) applied a hybrid AHP-VIKOR method to rank 12 private universities in Taiwan according to their performance from academicians’ viewpoint. They structured a 3-level criteria hierarchy based on the performance evaluation structure developed by the\xa0Taiwan Assessment and Evaluation Association. Zolfani and Ghadikolaei (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR68">2013</xref>) proposed a model in which balance score card (BSC) and MCDM techniques were used to evaluate\xa0performances of private universities in Iran. The\xa0Decision Making Trial and Evaluation Laboratory (DEMATEL) was used to reveal the\xa0relationships among the\xa0perspectives of BSC, the Analytic Network Process (ANP) was used to determine the\xa0importance of the\xa0criteria, and VIKOR was used to obtain the final ranking of the\xa0universities. On behalf of improving this methodology, both Özdemir and Tüysüz (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR43">2017</xref>) and Nazari-Shirkouhi et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR41">2020</xref>) integrated fuzzy logic into BSC-MCDM to cope with the ambiguity of decision-makers. Aliyev et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR5">2020</xref>) applied a Fuzzy AHP model to rank five universities in the United Kingdom regarding four criteria.', attributes={'id': 'Par15'}), StringElement('Another common topic about university ranking is research capacity. Duc et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR20">2020</xref>) proposed a new MCDM model that uses improved arithmetic operations of generalized fuzzy numbers. They applied this model to evaluate research capacity at Vietnam University. Su et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR55">2020</xref>) proposed a model that uses MCDM and output-oriented nonradial super\xa0efficiency Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) to evaluate the research efficiency of Chinese universities. There are few applications in the literature on university ranking problems based on the perspective of innovation. Chen and Chen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR19">2010</xref>) emphasized that university innovation could not be measured only by academic research papers, but also other factors such as ‘number of chair professors’ and ‘international academic interaction’. Therefore, the authors proposed a new MCDM model to evaluate universities’ innovation performance. They formed a decision support system that combines DEMATEL to reveal the relationships between criteria, fuzzy ANP to determine the criteria weights, and Technique for Order Performance by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) to rank the alternatives. Muhammad et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR37">2021</xref>) proposed an MCDM model to evaluate the usability of academic websites\xa0of\xa0higher education institutions. They used fuzzy AHP to determine criteria weights and compare alternatives.', attributes={'id': 'Par16'}), StringElement('A brand new perspective is sustainability. Puente et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR46">2020</xref>) proposed an integrated model for quality assessment and sustainability assessment for higher education institutions in Europe. A fuzzy DEMATEL model was used to reveal the\xa0relationships between criteria, a fuzzy ANP model was used to determine the\xa0weights of criteria, and finally, a Fuzzy Inference System was used to make final evaluations of higher education institutions. Arora et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR6">2020</xref>) Arora et al. applied fuzzy AHP to prioritize sustainability drivers of higher education institutions and revealed that environmental practices and social responsibility are the most critical drivers. Likewise, another challenging topic is lean philosophy. Kazancoglu and Ozkan-Ozen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR32">2019</xref>) proposed the fuzzy DEMATEL model to detect and rank important wastes in higher education institutions from the academic staff perspective. Klein et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR33">2021</xref>) determined wastes in higher education institutions and applied AHP to prioritize them and concluded that the most important wastes are loss of knowledge and overprocessing.', attributes={'id': 'Par17'}), StringElement('Evaluating universities from students’ viewpoints has been much sought after, especially in the last few years. Kabak and Dağdeviren (Kabak & Dağdeviren, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR27">2014</xref>) applied a hybrid MCDM method to understand Industrial Engineering students’ way of thinking in university choice. They used the ANP method to determine the\xa0weights of the\xa0criteria and the Preference Ranking Organization Method for Enrichment Evaluation (PROMETHEE) to obtain the final ranking. Goyal et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR23">2021</xref>) contributed to this topic by considering the uncertainty of student\xa0judgments through Fuzzy AHP. Nanath et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR40">2021</xref>) investigated differences in university choice factors pre and after the COVID-19 pandemic via one-way multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and ranked universities via AHP. Nojavan et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR42">2021</xref>) focused on academic units’ performance from students’ viewpoints in higher education. Hence, they proposed a model in which students\' opinions were received by\xa0a fuzzy SERVQUAL questionnaire, the\xa0criteria weights were determined by Fuzzy AHP, the final ranking was obtained by Fuzzy TOPSIS, and the\xa0efficiency of the\xa0units were revealed by Fuzzy DEA. Introducing a new perspective, Castro-Lopez et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR18">2021</xref>) proposed a hybrid AHP-Fuzzy Inference Systems method so that the\xa0reasons for university dropout and factors that affect the intention to remain in the university can be better understood.', attributes={'id': 'Par18'}), StringElement('As mentioned above, studies related to clustering or classification of universities for different purposes were also reviewed. For example, Valadkhani and Worthington (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR61">2006</xref>) clustered 36 universities in Austria according to research capacity per academic staff, Erdoǧmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>) clustered Turkish universities according to institutional size and performance by using hierarchical cluster analysis, Wang and Zha (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR62">2018</xref>) implemented three clustering methods to Chinese universities to cluster them according to systematic diversity, Perchinunno and Cazzolle (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR44">2020</xref>) applied clustering analysis to 780 international universities and revealed four groups according to sustainability, and etc.', attributes={'id': 'Par19'}), StringElement('A comprehensive literature review reveals that MCDM-based approaches are often used to solve university evaluation problems from different perspectives. Moreover, studies dealing with university evaluation from the student perspective do not include teaching and research factors. The evaluation of similar universities is not addressed in such studies, and the number of included universities has always been limited. Different MCDM methodologies are employed to handle the university ranking problem, especially for weighting criteria. In this study, the\xa0VIKOR methodology is extended with IVN-AHP to solve the university ranking problem.', attributes={'id': 'Par20'}), StringElement("This study considers both student satisfaction criteria\xa0and widespread teaching and research characteristics by focusing on these research gaps. Primarily, universities are clustered according to teaching and research characteristics, and then, universities are ranked within each cluster according to students' satisfaction. In this way, instead of ranking a large number of universities at once, it is possible to perform the proposed MCDM method to rank fewer universities within the clusters. A more sensitive, realistic, and effective evaluation of similar universities is obtained. A novel MCDM methodology that integrates IVN-AHP and VIKOR is presented for the first time in the decision-making literature. Furthermore, to the best of the authors' knowledge, it is the most comprehensive study in terms of the number of universities considered and the number of students who participated.", attributes={'id': 'Par21'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': [], 'title': 'Literature review'}, attributes={'id': 'Sec2'}), DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('The proposed methodology consists of two stages. At the first stage, universities are divided into different clusters via hierarchical clustering based on teaching and research characteristics. At the second stage, the predetermined criteria, which have been used to rank universities in a previous survey (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR29">2020</xref>), are weighted using the IVN-AHP methodology based on opinions taken from students from different universities. VIKOR is then employed to evaluate and rank the universities in each cluster using these weights. The methodology\xa0also has a subsidiary stage to compare cluster-based rankings with holistic rankings. The proposed integrated methodology is illustrated in Fig.\xa0<xref rid="Fig1" ref-type="fig">1</xref> and is theoretically detailed in the following subsections.<fig id="Fig1"><label>Fig.\xa01</label><caption><p>The proposed methodology</p></caption><graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Fig1_HTML" id="MO1"></graphic></fig>', attributes={'id': 'Par22'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('Dividing data into meaningful or useful groups ensures that\xa0algorithms generate more significant outputs. Based on the groups, formed for understanding (objects share common characteristics) or utility (characterizing clusters in terms of cluster prototypes), the outputs better reflect the people’s ways of analyzing and describing the natural structure of the domain (Tan & Steinbach, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR56">2006</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par23'}), StringElement('Cluster analysis (or clustering) is one of the most common ways to group objects based on several measurements made on each object individually. Within the frame of understanding the objects in the same groups, the key idea is to guarantee within-group similarity, and hence dissimilarity among the groups. For this purpose, there are two general types of clustering algorithms: hierarchical\xa0clustering and nonhierarchical clustering (Köhn & Hubert, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR34">2015</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par24'}), StringElement('Nonhierarchical algorithms produce nonoverlapping clusters, meaning an object belongs to one cluster. The algorithm requires a prespecified cluster number to assign an object to one of the clusters. However, hierarchical algorithms arrange the clusters into a natural hierarchy. This natural hierarchy produces a set of nested clusters in the form of a tree. Additionally, a prespecified cluster number is no need for hierarchical algorithms when useful in the absence of the information likely groups in the data.', attributes={'id': 'Par25'}), StringElement('In this study, to model each cluster separately rather than the entire heterogeneous dataset, a hierarchical clustering algorithm was used to group universities with similar teaching and research characteristics. Then, an\xa0individual comparison of each cluster is drawn through the proposed decision-making method.', attributes={'id': 'Par26'}), StringElement('The hierarchical clustering algorithm can be either agglomerative or divisive. The algorithm used in this study is agglomerative, which has widespread use, begins with n clusters (equal to the\xa0numbers of the object in the dataset) and continues progressively merging the two most similar (nearest) clusters untill all objects belong to one cluster. The divisive clustering algorithm has an\xa0inverse logic with the agglomerative algorithm. A formal procedure for the hierarchical clustering is expressed in Algorithm 1 (González-Cabrera et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR22">2021</xref>).<graphic position="anchor" http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Figa_HTML" id="MO2"></graphic>', attributes={'id': 'Par27'}), StringElement('Clusters have one or more objects. Hence, once the first iteration is applied and the nearest single objects are combined, the distance calculation between any two clusters (or a cluster and an object) is now needed to combine clusters. This distance calculation relies on the closeness of two clusters quantified by various linkage measures, such as minimum distance, average distance, centroid distance, and Ward’s method. On the other hand, the dissimilarity between two objects <italic toggle="yes">i</italic> and <italic toggle="yes">j</italic> when evaluating linkage between clusters is measured by a distance metric such as Euclidean, Cosine, Pearson’s correlation, and Minkowski.', attributes={'id': 'Par28'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': [], 'title': 'Hierarchical clustering'}, attributes={'id': 'Sec4'}), DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('The neutrosophic logic was developed by Smarandache (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR51">1998</xref>) as a more generalized version of fuzzy sets to cope with indeterminancy and ambiguity more comprehensively by extending fuzzy logic with a novel function named "uncertainty" (Kahraman et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR28">2020</xref>). Three functions are used to define a neutrosophic set <inline-formula id="IEq1"><alternatives><tex-math id="M1">\\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsmath}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{wasysym} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsfonts} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amssymb} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsbsy}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{mathrsfs}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{upgreek}\n\t\t\t\t\\setlength{\\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}\n\t\t\t\t\\begin{document}$$\\widetilde{{\\dddot A}}$$\\end{document}</tex-math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">A</mi><mo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">⃛</mo></mover><mo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">~</mo></mover></math><inline-graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Article_IEq1.gif"></inline-graphic></alternatives></inline-formula> in the universe <inline-formula id="IEq2"><alternatives><tex-math id="M3">\\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsmath}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{wasysym} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsfonts} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amssymb} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsbsy}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{mathrsfs}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{upgreek}\n\t\t\t\t\\setlength{\\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}\n\t\t\t\t\\begin{document}$$E$$\\end{document}</tex-math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">E</mi></math><inline-graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Article_IEq2.gif"></inline-graphic></alternatives></inline-formula>. position="anchor"></graphic></alternatives></disp-formula>', attributes={'id': 'Par34'}), 'The AHP method, whose fundamentals were firstly proposed by Myers and Alpert (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR39">1968</xref>). Then Saaty systematized and developed based on the logic of structuring a problem in hierarchical structure (Thor et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR58">2013</xref>). The AHP methodology sometimes fails to reflect opinions from decision-makers because of indeterminancy and ambiguity in information (Ayyildiz et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR8">2020</xref>). IVN-AHP can be used to handle indeterminacy and ambiguity with three functions to effectively\xa0integrate human thought into the\xa0decision-making process. In this study, the students’ satisfaction factors are weighted using the IVN-AHP methodology. The application steps of the methodology are given below.<def-list><def-item><term>Step 1.</term><def><p id="Par36">The criteria and evaluation scale are determined.</p></def></def-item><def-item><term>Step 2.</term><def><p id="Par37">Pairwise comparison matrix <inline-formula id="IEq13"><alternatives><tex-math id="M41">\\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsmath}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{wasysym} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsfonts} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amssymb} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsbsy}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{mathrsfs}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{upgreek}\n\t\t\t\t\\setlength{\\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}\n\t\t\t\t\\begin{document}$$\\left( {\\widetilde{\\dddot P}} \\right)$$\\end{document}</tex-math><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">P</mi><mo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">⃛</mo></mover><mo xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML">~</mo></mover></mfenced></math><inline-graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Article_IEq13.gif"></inline-graphic></alternatives></inline-formula> is constructed via linguistic terms. [], 'p': [StringElement('The VIKOR method was first presented by Opricovic (1998) for multi-criteria optimization of complex systems. VIKOR is a method that allows determining a consensual ranking and achieving a compromise solution according to the specified criteria. In the method, alternatives are evaluated according to criteria and a ranking is obtained by calculating proximity values to the ideal alternative (Tayyar & Arslan, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR57">2013</xref>). The steps of\xa0VIKOR are given below:<def-list><def-item><term>Step 1.</term><def><p id="Par46">The decision matrix is established to evaluate alternatives. 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('In 2020, 74 foundation and 129 state universities existed in Turkey. In the last decade, the number of students has increased more than twice in state universities and more than three times in foundation universities (YÖK, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR67">2021c</xref>). Although there is an existing methodology for ranking universities in some countries, there is no such ranking system at the national level in Turkey. Furthermore, studies on university preference and classification for Turkey are quite few, and these studies are considered insufficient in terms of both scope and content. Kabak and Dağdeviren (Kabak & Dağdeviren, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR27">2014</xref>) analyzed the\xa0factors for university selection and ranked universities in Turkey while only covering 15 universities and took the opinions of 50 students who are all engineering students. On the other hand, Erdoğmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>) clustered Turkish universities according to different points of view. In the study by Erdoğmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>), different weaknesses are faced in different clustering applications. For example, while universities were clustered according to their ranking scores, only 50 universities could be covered due to a lack of data; as for clustering in accordance with teaching performance, there was only one factor considered. Alternatively, global ranking systems mostly depend on academic research parameters (URAP Research Laboratory, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR60">2021</xref>) and fail to satisfy being multidirectional. As distinct from the\xa0existing literature, this study provides the\xa0handling of\xa0both global and local characteristics of universities by clustering them according to academic and teaching characteristics and ranking them within the clusters considering student perspectives. The study has two main stages: (i) dividing universities into different groups and (ii) ranking them in each group separately. One hundred\xa0and ninety-one universities are clustered based on the\xa0teaching and research characteristics of universities. Clustering before ranking (i) ensures the impartial ranking of universities by only comparing universities that have students with similar expectations; (ii) can lead to getting smaller, more meaningful rankings instead of a multitude ranking which is difficult to interpret; (iii) prevents moving away from the reality of the ideal alternative that is needed for VIKOR by avoiding ranking many alternatives. Following the clustering, the universities are ranked through the proposed MCDM method for each cluster. The data reflecting the academic achivements of universities are collected from the\xa0official data of the\xa0Turkish Council of Higher Education (YÖK, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR67">2021c</xref>) and SciVal tool provided by Elsevier (SciVal, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR49">2021</xref>). The data that quantify students’ satisfaction are collected from the report of Turkish Universities Satisfaction Research (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR29">2020</xref>) by UniAr (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR30">2021</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par59'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('As stated in the introduction, the foundation year is used to observe whether a longer service time of a university can lead to greater student satisfaction. The number of academicians of a university might be a kind of evidence for abundant sources that can be used for a wide range of demands. The number of academic outputs per academician is another factor in clustering universities. Here, academic output refers to the\xa0total number of articles, reviews, conference papers, books, and book chapters indexed in Scopus database.\xa0The other factors are considered signs of the academic outlook\xa0quality. Besides, these factors, which form the basis of our study for the clustering of universities, are factors that have been used\xa0frequently in previous studies to classify universities. Table <xref rid="Tab1" ref-type="table">1</xref> presents some examples of these studies\xa0that use these factors and their derivatives.<table-wrap id="Tab1"><label>Table 1</label><caption><p>Summary of related literature on similar factors in university clustering</p></caption><table frame="hsides" rules="groups"><thead><tr><th align="left">Factor</th><th align="left">Related sources</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td align="left">The number of academicians</td><td align="left">Abbott and Doucouliagos (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR1">2003</xref>), Aliyev et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR5">2020</xref>), Erdoǧmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>), Su et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR55">2020</xref>), Valadkhani and Worthington (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR61">2006</xref>), Wang and Zha (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR62">2018</xref>)</td></tr><tr><td align="left">The number of students per academician</td><td align="left">Abbott and Doucouliagos (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR1">2003</xref>), Aliyev et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR5">2020</xref>), Erdoǧmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>), Su et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR55">2020</xref>), Wang and Zha (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR62">2018</xref>), Wu et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR63">2012</xref>)</td></tr><tr><td align="left">The number of academic outputs per academician</td><td align="left">Abbott and Doucouliagos (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR1">2003</xref>), Alaşehir et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR17">2015</xref>), Chen and Chen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR19">2010</xref>), Erdoǧmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>), Nazari-Shirkouhi et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR41">2020</xref>), Porter, (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR45">1990</xref>), Valadkhani and Worthington (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR61">2006</xref>), Wang and Zha (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR62">2018</xref>), Wu et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR63">2012</xref>)</td></tr><tr><td align="left">The number of citations per academician</td><td align="left">Alaşehir et al. (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR55">2020</xref>)</td></tr><tr><td align="left">Foundation year</td><td align="left">Erdoǧmuş and Esen (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR21">2016</xref>), Soutar and Turner (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR54">2002</xref>)</td></tr></tbody></table></table-wrap>', attributes={'id': 'Par60'}), StringElement('The factors are continuous and\xa0numerical variables. factors through agglomerative hierarchical clustering. For the best division, the most appropriate alternatives of hyperparameters are determined by testing all possible combinations of \xa0the\xa0number of clusters, distance metric, and linkage measures between clusters. The quality of clusters obtained for the combinations are compared over the mean silhouette score. The\xa0Silhouette score (Layton et al., <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR36">2013</xref>), which bases on the distance of an object to others in the same cluster and the\xa0distance of the object to objects in the nearest cluster, is a measure of cluster density.', attributes={'id': 'Par62'}), StringElement('The best combination of the hyperparameters for agglomerative clustering is determined according to 336 different combinations consisting of cluster numbers from 3 to 10; average, centroid, complete, median, single, Ward and Mcquaitty linkages and Euclidean, Manhattan, maximum, Pearson, Spearman and canberra distance metrics. Accordingly, the optimal hierarchical clustering hyperparameter set with the highest silhouette score 0.5071, as shown in Fig.\xa0<xref rid="Fig2" ref-type="fig">2</xref>, for the separation of the universities discussed in the study is as follows: 3 clusters, Euclidean distance and average linkage.<fig id="Fig2"><label>Fig. 2</label><caption><p>The silhouette plot for the\xa0optimal hierarchical agglomerative clustering</p></caption><graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Fig2_HTML" id="MO3"></graphic></fig>', attributes={'id': 'Par63'}), StringElement('By the\xa0average linkage, the closeness between two clusters is defined as the average distance. The method averages the distances between each object in the first cluster and all objects in the second cluster (Yim & Ramdeen, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR64">2015</xref>). Finally, the clusters that need to be combined are the two with the smallest average linkage distance calculated as in Eq.\xa0<xref rid="Equ20" ref-type="disp-formula">20</xref>.<disp-formula id="Equ20"><label>20</label><alternatives><tex-math id="M135">\\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsmath}\n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{wasysym} \n\t\t\t\t\\usepackage{amsfonts} = \\frac{1}{{kl}}\\sum\\limits_{{i = 1}}^{k} {\\sum\\limits_{{j = 1}}^{l} {\\left\\| {\\vec{x}_{i} - \\vec{y}_{j}^{2} } \\right\\|} }$$\\end{document}</tex-math><math the clusters can be seen in Fig.\xa0<xref rid="Fig3" ref-type="fig">3</xref>. The figure illustrates the spread of the factors according to the clusters.<fig id="Fig3"><label>Fig. 3</label><caption><p>The spread of each factor by clusters</p></caption><graphic http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink href="11192_2022_4534_Fig3_HTML" id="MO4"></graphic></fig>', attributes={'id': 'Par67'}), StringElement('According to Fig.\xa0<xref rid="Fig3" ref-type="fig">3</xref>, Cluster-1 consists of both state and foundation universities with a relatively low number of academicians. The universities in this cluster have lower outputs per academician, although some outliers exist. The universities in Cluster-1 probably fail to recruit a qualified and sufficient number of academics. Cluster-2 corresponds to well-established universities with a higher population of both academicians and students. The universities in Cluster-2 have a\xa0longer service-time (note that the smaller normalized factor value for the\xa0foundation year is the longer service-time). Cluster-3 and Cluster-1 are similar in terms of factors except for the citations per academician and output per academician. The\xa0universities gathered in Cluster-3 have the highest values of these normalized factors. In this regard, the universities in this cluster care about the success of academicians without concern\xa0for the number of academicians. Having a small number of successful academicians leads to the cluster having a high number of academic outputs per academician.', attributes={'id': 'Par68'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': [], 'title': 'Clustering of Universities'}, attributes={'id': 'Sec8'}), DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('The proposed IVN-AHP VIKOR model was performed for Turkish universities. Therefore, this study determines the weights of each criterion using the MCDM approach. Thus, it is aimed at obtaining more meaningful results by prioritizing the criteria while evaluating universities. In this respect, the study differs from articles oriented to university ranking based on\xa0student satisfaction in the literature. In addition, both the\xa0criterion weights and university evaluations were determined using MCDM approaches. In this study, for the first time in the literature, the VIKOR method is extended to the IVN-AHP method to solve complex decision-making problems. In this context, this study offers innovations in both theory and application.", attributes={'id': 'Par70'}), StringElement('The criteria are evaluated by 50 students from 13 different universities in Turkey to construct the pairwise comparison matrix. The students are asked to express their opinions to prioritize the criteria through a questionnaire. The\xa0students evaluate the criteria by using the linguistic variables given in Table <xref rid="Tab4" ref-type="table">4</xref>. The interval-valued neutrosophic scale corresponding to the linguistic variables shown in Table <xref rid="Tab4" ref-type="table">4</xref> is used for this evaluation.<table-wrap determination of the\xa0criteria weights, the\xa0opinions of the\xa0students for the evaluation of universities are provided from Turkish University Satisfaction Research (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR29">2020</xref>). In this framework, 39,386 undergraduate students\' opinions are received from 191 different universities. While 125 state\xa0universities and 66 foundation universities are included, only two universities from Turkey could\xa0not be covered by this study due to their insufficient number of students.', attributes={'id': 'Par74'}), StringElement('In the report, student selection is conducted according to the\xa0quota sampling, and at least 75 students\' opinions are taken from each university. According to quota sampling, different disciplinary students are reached. The most participating faculties are the\xa0Faculty of Engineering and Architecture with 17.8%, the\xa0Faculty of Economics and Administrative Sciences with 14.8%, and the\xa0Faculty of Science and Literature with 14.4%. In the questionnaire, participants are asked to evaluate the university at which they are studying according to six criteria on a Likert scale\xa0of\xa00–100 points. Thus, university evaluation matrices for each cluster are constructed for each criterion. The data used in this study are compiled from the UNIAR yearly report for 2020 (Karadağ & Yücel, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR29">2020</xref>).', attributes={'id': 'Par75'}), StringElement('The universities are evaluated according to predetermined criteria for each cluster. Therefore, the VIKOR methodology is applied to rank universities for each cluster in Turkey. According to this report, 5 Turkish Universities ("itu", "hacettepe", "metu", "istanbul", "ankara") are existing in all of these rankings, 3 universities ("bilkent", "boun", "ege") are in ten lists, 1 university ("ku") is in nine lists and 2 universities ("sabanciu", "atatürk") are in eight lists. As for the results of the proposed clustering method, the universities that exist in all 11 organizations\' lists of leading universities ("itu", "hacettepe", "metu", "istanbul", "ankara") are in the same cluster, namely Cluster-2. Although "ozyegin " and "acibadem" are foundation universities, and "agu" is a state university supported by the foundation, the common feature of these three universities is that the amount of expenditure per student is more than 20,000 Turkish Lira (YÖK, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR66">2021b</xref>). In the same cluster, "akev", "hakkari" and "bitliseren" universities are ranked as the last three universities. On the other hand, universities that are in the first three places, "ege", "hacettepe", and "itu", are outstanding in terms of overall program occupancy rate. DictElement({'alternatives': [], 'speech': [], 'notes': [], 'glossary': [], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': [StringElement('The competition between universities is getting challenging with the increasing number of institutions. Therefore, universities should improve themselves in areas such as research and education and even make improvements by taking student satisfaction into account. In this study, a novel framework is established to address university ranking. In this framework, the\xa0clustering of universities according to teaching and research characteristics is performed in the first stage, and ranking universities according to student satisfaction, in-cluster and general, is obtained in the second stage. Six factors representing the characteristics of universities in the teaching and research areas were used in the clustering analysis: “foundation year”, “the number of academicians”, “the number of students per academician”, “the number of citations per academician”, and “the number of outputs per academician”. In the second stage, to prioritize the\xa0evaluation criteria which are "learning experience", " campus life", "academic support and interest", "management ", "learning opportunities and resources", and "personal development and career support”, IVN-AHP is used. The results of IVN-AHP are used in the VIKOR method as criteria weights to reveal the\xa0ranking.', attributes={'id': 'Par93'}), StringElement('The contributions of this study to the literature can be summarized as follows: (1) A novel clustering-based\xa0MCDM methodology is presented to handle MCDM problems with more alternatives; (2) Both global and local characteristics of universities are handled together; (3) The factors related to university segmentation are determined by literature review; (4) The most important criteria regarding university ranking by student satisfaction are determined by IVN-AHP; (5) The\xa0university ranking problem is modeled as an MCDM problem; (6) A brief literature review on university ranking problem is presented; (7) The universities from Turkey are clustered by hierarchical clustering; (8) Universities are evaluated and ranked through VIKOR; (9) To the best of our knowledge, this paper presents IVN-AHP integrated VIKOR methodology for the first time; (10) A real case application for evaluating universities in Turkey is presented to show the applicability of the proposed methodology.', attributes={'id': 'Par94'}), StringElement('The results show that there is no significant difference between the weights of the criteria that affect students\' perceptions of university satisfaction, while "learning experience" is the most important criterion, followed by "personal development and career support" and "learning opportunities and resources". In other respects, the fact that foundation universities take most of the\xa0first places is a valuable insight for authorized institutions such as The Council of Higher Education (YÖK). Moreover, the results of this study have guiding features for universities in Turkey, as they show their position in terms of student satisfaction.', attributes={'id': 'Par95'}), StringElement('The proposed hybrid methodology can be used to solve complex decision-making problems. The quality of services in different public or private institutions can be evaluated using the proposed MCDM approach. The proposed methodology can also be applied to different types of educational institution, such as primary school, high school. This study can be expanded by interviewing more experts or the number of factors and/or criteria can be increased.', attributes={'id': 'Par96'})], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': [], 'title': 'Conclusion'}, attributes={'id': 'Sec14'})], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': []}

[], 'question-wrap': [], 'related-object': [], 'fig': [], 'ref-list': [], 'fig-group': [], 'p': ['The first research conducted on violence against women in the university context in Spain reveals that 62% of the students know of or have experienced situations of this kind within the university institutions, but only 13% identify these situations in the first place. Two main interrelated aspects arise from the data analysis: not identifying and acknowledging violent situations, and the lack of reporting them. Policies and actions developed by Spanish universities need to be grounded in two goals: intransigence toward any kind of violence against women, and bystander intervention, support, and solidarity with the victims and with the people supporting the victims.'], 'table-wrap-group': [], 'x': [], 'disp-formula': [], 'question': [], 'supplementary-material': [], 'question-wrap-group': [], 'media': [], 'table-wrap': [], 'answer-set': [], 'def-list': [], 'mml:math': [], 'sec': [], 'code': [], 'boxed-text': [], 'object-id': [], 'disp-formula-group': [], 'explanation': [], 'list': [], 'tex-math': [], 'answer': [], 'disp-quote': [], 'address': [], 'statement': [], 'verse-group': [], 'graphic': [], 'array': [], 'ack': [], 'fn-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'chem-struct-wrap': [], 'preformat': [], 'block-alternatives': []}], 'issue-title-group': [], 'volume-id': [], 'funding-group': [], 'trans-abstract': [], 'issue-sponsor': [], 'conference': [], 'pub-date': [ListElement(['29', '1', '2016'], attributes={'pub-type': 'epub'}), ListElement(['11', '2016'], attributes={'pub-type': 'ppub'})], 'aff-alternatives': [], 'email': [], 'support-group': [], 'related-article': [], 'volume': ['22'], 'article-categories': {'series-title': [], 'series-text': [], 'subj-group': [DictElement({'compound-subject': [], 'subject': ['Articles'], 'subj-group': []}, attributes={'subj-group-type': 'heading'})]}, 'title-group': {'subtitle': ['Findings From the First Study of Violence Against Women on Campuses in Spain'], 'trans-title-group': [], 'alt-title': [], 'article-title': 'Breaking the Silence at Spanish Universities'}, 'author-notes': {'fn': [], 'x': [], 'p': [], 'corresp': [StringElement('Rosa Valls, University of Barcelona, Passeig de la Vall d’Hebron, 171, 08035 Barcelona, Spain.
